V436 Per.source: DEBCat and Southworth & Bowman (2022) Table 3. Tess sector 18 SAP data analysed with JKTEBOP. Teffs reproduced from Janik et al. (2003)
V436 Per.desc: An eccentric orbit with the secondary eclipse near phase 0.4 and depths of ~0.4 and ~0.15 mag. The long period means only one of each eclipse is observed. Star B is both larger (k~1.1) and more luminous (J~1.04) than Star A which, coupled with partial eclipses and SLF variability, will likely make this difficult to predict. Southworth & Bowman found solutions where k=0.69(3), 0.84(2) and 1.10(3), with that last adopted; poor predictions may lead JKTEBOP to the wrong solution.
V436 Per.notes: bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; control fit of S18 SAP data (period, PE and LD params fixed at published values) yields MAE~0.0031;

V539 Ara.source: DEBCat and Southworth & Bowman (2022) Table 3. Tess sectors 13 and 39 SAP data separately analysed with JKTEBOP (due to apsidal motion). Teffs reproduced from Clausen (1996).
V539 Ara.desc: An eccentric orbit with eclipses of approximate depth 0.45 and 0.40 mag and the secondary near phase 0.45. The presence of apsidal motion makes it preferable to fit the sectors separately. Primary fractional radius of 0.22 is beyond JKTEBOP's usually recommended maximum (0.2). This and the presence of SLF variability could make it difficult to predict and fit.
V539 Ara.notes: bP label derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; qphot label from published masses; control fit of sector 13 SAP data yields MAE~0.01 (S39 worse);

MU Cas.source: DEBCat and Lacy et al. (2004) [tables 4 & 5] who used ground based Bessel V-band photometry. 6 TESS sectors now available when searched on TIC rather than name.
MU Cas.why_exclude: Cannot get a good match to published params with control fit, especially k. Published characterisation not suitable as labels as I suspect TESS photometry will yield significant updates.
MU Cas.desc: A pair of similar B5 V stars in a 9.65 d elliptical orbit. The eclipses are approximately 0.45 and 0.44 mag deep, with the secondary at phase 0.62. The published characterisation predates TESS and it has not been possible to acheive a usable control fit which matches the published parameters (especially k).
MU Cas.notes: k calculated from rB/rA as published value based on k==rA/rB; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; best control fit is with s24 and yields MAE 0.023 (with poor fit to k; 1.06 not 1.14);

IQ Per.source: DEBCat and Lacy & Frueh (1985) tables 6, 7 & 8 (V-band) - based on non-TESS photometry. TESS sectors 19 and 59 now available.
IQ Per.why_exclude: awaiting John's characterization, although note that rA > 0.2
IQ Per.notes: J(TESS), logLA and logLB approximated from T_effs and radii; w, ecosw & esinw approximated update (apsidal motion); bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; current control fit is poor at MAE~0.24 (awaiting JKT characterization);

psi Cen.source: DEBCat and Bruntt et al. (2006) Table 2 based on WIRE photometry and JKTEBOP. We have access to TESS sectors 38 & 65 120 s SAP photometry (38 has incomplete eclipses).
psi Cen.why_exclude: Unstable control fit; slight deviations from published params and we loose the best fit.
psi Cen.label: $\mathrm{\psi}$ Cen
psi Cen.desc: A highly eccentric orbit with transit depths of ~0.25 and ~0.15 mag and the secondary after phase 0.8. The period of 38.8 d is longer than a single TESS sector; we use both 38 & 65 to give the most coverage.
psi Cen.notes: bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; logLA & logLB derived from R and Teff; qphot, gravA & gravB from paper (pp 654); control fit of SAP flux of sectors 38 & 65, with published qphot & gravA/B values fixed, yields MAE~0.056 however it's an unstable fit;

V402 Lac.source: DEBCAT and Baroch et al. (2022) Tables 10 and 11. TESS sector 16 SAP flux analysed with WD (with preliminary fit with JKTEBOP).
V402 Lac.why_exclude: Unable to get good control fit; likely too distorted form JKTEBOP as stated in the source paper where WD code was used for analysis.
V402 Lac.desc: An eccentric orbit with the secondary beyond phase 0.6 and significantly shallower than primary despite their similar radii. This will make k and J difficult to predict. Baroch & Gimenez used the WD code for fitting as they considered the components too distorted for JKTEBOP.
V402 Lac.notes: e=0.376 (fixed); rA_plus_rB & k & ecosw & esinw derived from table 11; J approximated from Teff; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; bbest control fit (fixed at published qphot and L3) gives MAE~0.38 which is not usable (likely components too distorted for JKTEBOP simplified model); without fixing L3 fits are even worse with a large negative L3;

V1229 Tau.source: DEBCat and Southworth et al. (2023), Table I. TESS sectors 42-44 SAP flux analysed with JKTEBOP version 43.
V1229 Tau.desc: An inclined, circular orbit with shallow primary (~0.10 mag) and secondary (~0.05 mag) partial eclipses, reflection and ellipsoidal effects. These shallow, partial eclipses present a challange to predicting and fitting k and J. We use the published spectroscopic light-ratio and LD parameters from Southworth et al. (2023) with sectors 42 to 44 for fitting.
V1229 Tau.notes: e=0.0 & ω=0.0 (fixed); bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; best fit using SAP photometry on sector 42 only and fixing the published lrat and LD params yields MAE~0.029

V889 Aql.source: DEBCAT and Baroch et al. (2022) Tables 9 and 10. Used SAP flux extracted from TESS sectors 14 and 40 FFIs analysed with JKTEBOP and all params published. TESS sector 40 & 54 600 s timeseries data now available.
V889 Aql.desc: A highly eccentric orbit with the secondary eclipse before phase 0.4. This coupled with the stars having similar radii make k and J difficult to predict and fit. We use sector 40 timeseries data and the published spectroscopic light-ratio for fitting. Sector 40 shows some long term trends which our detrending is not removing however this does not appear to be overly detrimental to the predictions or fitting.
V889 Aql.notes: ecosw & esinw derived from table 9; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; best control fit with sector 54 SAP flux, fixed published period & lrat yields MAE~0.005;
V889 Aql.author: TESS-SPOC

WW Aur.source: DEBCat and Southworth et al. (2005) who use EBOP (with mods to fit rA+rB & k and to use MRQMIN) for fitting of observations from the 1970s. We use V-band fitting results (Table 10). Available TESS sectors 20, 43-45, 60 & 71-73 at 120 s cadence.
WW Aur.desc: An inclined circular orbit showing partial eclipses of approximately 0.64 and 0.55 mag. The combination of partial eclipses and stars of similar radius makes predicting and fitting k, J & inc a challenge. Published work based on legacy photometry whereas we have used TESS data.
WW Aur.notes: e=0.0 & ω=0.0 & L3=0 (fixed); bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; best control fit is sector 20 only SAP flux which yields MAE~0.031 (allowing L3 to fit);

V788 Cen.source: DEBCat and Graczyk et al. (2022) (Table 8) who use WD for fitting SAP flux of 2nd half of sector 37 (as least affected by starspots), leaving sector 10 unused.
V788 Cen.desc: An inclined circular orbit showing partial eclipses of approximately 0.19 and 0.16 mag.
V788 Cen.notes: e=0.0 & ω=0.0 fixed; J from trial JKTEBOP fit; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; control fit on SAP flux of 2nd half of S37 with L3 fixed at published value yields MAE~0.021

RR Lyn.source: Rediscussion VII, Table II (with third light). TESS sector 20 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 41.
RR Lyn.desc: An eccentric orbit with eclipses of approximately 0.35 and 0.25 mag and the secondary near phase 0.45. Evidence of delta-Scuti & gamma-Dor pulsations. Our labels are taken from the solution with third light.
RR Lyn.notes: bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; control fit on sector 20 using published LD params and flattening between eclipses yields MAE~0.006; predictions need to be very good, especially inc, as there is a nearby fit with inc~86, J~1.3 and MAE~0.36 which is attractive;

V362 Pav.source: DEBCat and Graczyk et al. (2022) Table 8 who use WD for fitting of SAP fluxes of 2nd half of Sector 13.
V362 Pav.desc: An inclined slightly eccentric orbit with shallow transits of approximately 0.2 and 0.03 mag and clear ellipsoidal effect. Star B is signifantly smaller, less luminous and less massive. The published parameters include a significant negative third light value.
V362 Pav.notes: J from trial JKTEBOP fit; rA_plus_rB & k derived from rA & rB in table 8; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; control fit of 2nd half of S13 SAP fluxes with L3 fixed at 0 and qphot fixed at spectroscopic value yields MAE~0.024 (however unable to replicate esinw - always get positive value unless fixed);

HO Tel.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion XX, Table III. (WD params) TESS sector 67 initial analysis with JKTEBOP version 43 to get ephemeris and then fully with JKTWD/WD2004.
HO Tel.why_exclude: Cannot get a reliable control fit as the component are likely too distorted for JKTEBOP (rA=0.2575 and rB=0.2325).
HO Tel.desc: An inclined circular orbit of 1.6 d with eclipse depths of approximiately 0.45 and 0.4 mag. The two components have fractional radii of 0.26 and 0.23 and are likely too distorted for JKTEBOP to accurately model.
HO Tel.notes: rA_plus_rB & k calculated from rA and rB; ecc, omega and Poincare elements set to zero as published; bP calculated from rA and inc (with ecc == zero); J approximated from Teff values; best control fit of sector 67 yields MAE~0.069 but is unreliable (e.g. O-C for J is -0.14)
HO Tel.author: TESS-SPOC

V456 Cyg.source: DEBCat and Van Reeth et al. (2022) Table 1. TESS sectors 14 and 15 fitted with JKTEBOP version 42. SpT and logLA from Bakis et al. (2014).
V456 Cyg.why_exclude: Components too large, at rA=0.27 and rB=0.26, for JKTEBOP simplified model.
V456 Cyg.desc: A tight circular orbit of just 0.9 d with distinct eclipses at 0.6 and 0.4 mag. Variability is seen in the light curve from pulsations dicussed in the source article. Both fractional radii are > 0.2, outside the range normally deemed suitable for fitting with JKTEBOP, but it was used in the source article and we are able to achieve a similar fit.
V456 Cyg.notes: e=0 & ω=0 (fixed); bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; logLB=0.78(5) from from Bakis+ logLA and Van Reeth+ Light Ratio; control fit of sectors 14 and 15 yields MAE~0.012;

GW Eri.source: DEBCat and Graczyk et al. (2022) who use WD for fitting sector 31 (table 8).
GW Eri.desc: An inclined circuler orbit with partial eclipses of similar depths at approximately 0.27 mag. With the stars have similar radii and luminosities, predicting and fitting k, J & inc will be challenging.
GW Eri.notes: e=0 & ω=0 (fixed); rA_plus_rB & k derived from rA & rB in table 8; J from trial JKTEBOP fit; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; control fit on sector 31 yields MAE~0.0046;

OO Peg.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion XVIII, Table II. TESS sector 55 TESS-SPOC/SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 43.
OO Peg.desc: A circular orbit with clear primary and secondary eclipses of approximately 0.38 and 0.35 mag.
OO Peg.notes: e=0 & ω=0 (fixed); bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; control fit on S55, with masked range and LD params from source article and L3 fixed at zero yields MAE~0.021;
OO Peg.author: TESS-SPOC

CW Eri.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion XVII, Table III. TESS sectors 4 and 31 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 43.
CW Eri.desc: A slightly eccentric orbit with clear primary and secondary eclipses of 0.46 and 0.40 mag and evidence of ellipsoidal variation.
CW Eri.notes: bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; control fit on sectors 31 with fixed qphot (as used in source paper) gives MAE~0.005

ZZ Boo.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion XII, Table II. TESS sectors 23 & 50 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 42.
ZZ Boo.desc: A circular orbit with similar eclipses at approximately 0.65 mag each. With the stars having similar size and luminosity, predicting and fitting k, J and inc is expected to be a challenge.
ZZ Boo.notes: e=0 & ω=0 (fixed); bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; control fit uses quality flags and LD params from source article, with sector 50 giving an MAE~0.001;

V570 Per.source: Rediscussion XIV, Table II. TESS sectors 18 and 58 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 43.
V570 Per.desc: An inclined circular orbit with variability due to starspots, evidence of the ellipsoidal effect and shallow eclipses at approximately 0.11 & 0.1 mag. In the source article a spectroscopic light ratio was required to constrain the fit, and we adopt the published value here.
V570 Per.notes: e=0 & ω=0 & L3=0 (fixed); bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; control fit includes time masks, LD params, fixed L3 and lrat from source article and sector 18 to give an MAE~0.0078

AN Cam.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion IV, Table II.  TESS sectors 19, 25, and 26 (timeseries data from FFI) analysed with JKTEBOP version 41.
AN Cam.desc: A highly eccentric 20.1 d orbit with the secondary eclipse near phase 0.8 and eclipse depths of approximately 0.6 and 0.5 mag.  The analysis in the source article used early TESS FFI observations of 1800 s cadence, here we use sectors 52 and 53 timeseries data (subsequent to publication) which has a cadence of 600 s. Primary eclipses are transits and whereas the secondary eclipses are partial.
AN Cam.notes: L3=0 (fixed); bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; source article based sectors 19, 25 & 26 FFIs - we use sectors 52 & 53 @ 600 s cadence to get full coverage of the orbit giving MAE~0.015;
AN Cam.author: TESS-SPOC

IT Cas.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion XIII, Table II (sector 17). TESS sectors 17, 24 and 57 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 43.
IT Cas.desc: An eccentric orbit with low inclination and similar eclipses of approximately 0.7 mag depth. The two components are similar and it expected that k, J and inc will be challenging to predict and fit.
IT Cas.notes: Using values from table II, Sector 24; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; best control fit with S24, including clipped regions and sector specific LD param from source article, gives MAE~0.0025;

V455 Aur.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion V, Table II. TESS sector 20 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 41. TESS sectors 60 and 73 released subsequent to publication.
V455 Aur.desc: A slightly eccentric, inclined orbit with eclipse depths of approximately 0.33 and 0.3 mag and a third non-eclipsing component in 4200 d orbit. While the eclipsing components are of similar radius their luminosities differ, with the source article publishing a light ratio of 0.859±0.031.
V455 Aur.notes: bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; control fit on S20 with published LD params gives MAE~0.0020;

V505 Per.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion VI, Table II. TESS sector 18 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 41. TESS sector 58 observations released subsequent to publication.
V505 Per.desc: An incloned circular orbit with similar primary and secondary eclipses of approximately 0.5 mag. The similarity of the components' radii will likely make predicting and fitting k and J challenging. There is some distortion of the light curve near BTJD 1791 which we treat with lightkurve flatten.
V505 Per.notes: e=0 & ω=0 & L3=0 (fixed); bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; control fit on S18, with published (fixed) L3 and LD params, gives MAE~0.0031;

AI Phe.source: DEBCat and Maxted et al. (2020), Tables 2 and 3. The Southworth analysis of TESS sector 2 PDCSAP flux (K, JKTEBOP v38, quad LD law).  Teff and subsequently calculated L from Kirkby+Kent et al. (2016)
AI Phe.desc: An eccentric orbit with the secondary occuring before phase 0.5. Star B is significantly larger and evolved with k~1.6. Only sector 2 shows both eclipses with sectors 29 and 69 having incomplete eclipses. Primary eclipses are transits and whereas the secondary eclipses are partial.
AI Phe.notes: J calculated from T_effs and corroborated with JKTEBOP fit with fixed params from run K; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; control fit using SAP flux and fixed period (as in Maxted paper) yields MAE~0.0063; need good predictions for a statisfactory fit - there's a 2nd set of params nearby with J~0.85 which is very attractive;

ZZ Uma.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion XI, Table II. TESS sectors 14, 21, 41, 47 and 48 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 42.
ZZ Uma.desc: A circular orbit with transits of approximately 0.65 and 0.35 mag and significant variability due to starspot activity.
ZZ Uma.notes: e=0 & ω=0 & L3=0 (fixed); bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; best control fit with half of sector S21 (to minimise variability due to star spots) and published LD params (fixed), gives MAE~0.012;

QR Hya.source: DEBCat and Graczyk et al. (2022) table 8 who use WD for fitting TESS sector 9 PDCSAP data (omitted sector 36 due to starspots). Sector 63 released subsequent to publication.
QR Hya.desc: An inclined orbit with partial eclipses of approximately 0.30 and 0.28 mag.
QR Hya.notes: L3=0 (fixed); rA_plus_rB & k derived from rA & rB in table 8; J from trial JKTEBOP fit; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; control fit with cleanest subset of S9 PDCSAP data (masked and flattened) gives MAE~0.0059; predictions need to be very good (especially rA_plus_rB) to get a satisfactory fit;

V963 Cen.source: DEBCat and Graczyk et al. (2022) who use WD for fitting. Assuming TESS sector 38 was used. Sectors 64 and 65 have since been released.
V963 Cen.why_exclude: Unable to get a reliable and stable control fit.
V963 Cen.desc: A highly eccentric orbit showing partial eclipses of approximately 0.4 and 0.15 mag with the secondary near phase 0.3. Some long period variability is seen in the light curve. The two components are very similar in radius and luminosity which will make predicting and fitting in k and J challenging.
V963 Cen.notes: rA_plus_rB & k derived from rA & rB in table 8; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; best control fit with S38, with flattening to dampen variability, yields MAE 0.048 (but it's not good, with O-C of 0.14 for k and JKTEBOP Task 8 throwing up many 'failure to converge' retries and giving >15% 1-sigma error bar of k);

V454 Aur.source: Rediscussion XIX, Table II.  TESS sectors 20, 43, 44, 45, 60, 71, 72 and 73 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 43.
V454 Aur.desc: A highly eccentric 27.2 d orbit with eclipses of approximately 0.4 and 0.3 mag and the secondary after phase 0.65. It is in an unusual configuration with Star A both smaller and cooler than Star B, as the primary eclipse (of Star A) occurs when the stars are closer in their orbits than the secondary. We use sectors 43-45 to get sufficient coverage for a control fit.
V454 Aur.notes: L3=0 (fixed); bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; a very difficult fit - need R19 LD algo+coeffs and multiple sectors to get a fit giving a MAE~0.0032 (however it's not very reliable; we get many 'failed to converge', 'gaussj' or 'haywire' warnings when runing a JKTEBOP task 8 on it);

V530 Ori.source: DEBCat and Torres et al. (2014) who used JKTEBOP with various non-TESS photometry sources.
V530 Ori.desc: A G+M pair in an eccentric 6.1 d orbit showing partial primary eclipses of ~0.5 mag and shallow secondary transits of ~0.06 mag. Some variability detected; probably from star spots on the primary component.
V530 Ori.notes: J in TESS bandpass calculated from T_effs; bP derived from rA, inc, e & esinw; control fit on TESS S33, with flattening to dampen variability, yields MAE 0.0090;

CM Dra.source: DEBCAT and Martin et al. (2024), Table I. TESS Sectors 16, 19, 22-26, 49-52 (all slow) and 56-59 (200 s) analysed with EXOPLANET. SpT, Teff & logL from Morales et al. (2009).
CM Dra.desc: Two M-dwarfs in a nearly circular, slightly inclined 1.27 d orbit. Eclipses are approximately 0.76 and 0.73 mag deep. Lightcurves show frequent flares however these should have little affect on the fit.
CM Dra.notes: Martin values; L3=0 (fixed); just a single sector needed for a good fit, as the period is so short, yielding MAE~0.0086;
CM Dra.author: TESS-SPOC
